_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan executive summary to comply with 40 CRF ? 68.155 as amended by [61 FR 31726, June 20, 1996, as amended at 69 FR 18831, Apr. 9, 2004].

Location: Air Liquide Electronics US LP, 3322 Road ?N? NE, Moses Lake, WA





THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES AT THE STATIONARY SOURCE:

At the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP facility located in Moses Lake, WA, several measures are utilized to prevent accidental release. 

ALEUS?s 3322 Road ?N? NE location utilizes the following accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source: 
   -systems are designed by engineers
   -standard operating procedures to ensure the facility is operated as designed
   -?management of change? to ensure the covered process is not altered without a safety review 
   -operator training to ensure correct operating procedure (SOP) 
   -operator training to ensure emergency response including shutting down systems to limit the impact of potential release
   -enforcement of area electrical classification and conforming equipment
   -safety training for all personnel on site





THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

The substance which triggers 40 CFR 68 compliance is hydrogen, stored in both liquid and gas form.

The primary function of the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 3322 Road ?N? NE is to supply bulk gasses to our customer via pipeline on a 24 hour, 365-day basis. The facility manufactures a flammable gas by process of catalytic reformation.

During the process of manufacturing flammable gas, raw material flammable gas is combined with steam at high temperatures, which causes a reaction releasing product flammable gas. 

Flammable gas is stored in liquid form in stationary bulk tanks.

The ALEUS stationary source located at 3322 Road ?N? NE, includes two 20,000 gallon (jacketed vacuum insulated cryogenic, horizontal) tanks of flammable gas, one 20,260 gallon (jacketed vacu

um insulated cyrogenic, horizontal) tank of flammable gas, two 30,000 gallon (single walled, horizontal) tanks of flammable gas, and additional flammable gases within the process. 





THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those to mitigate risk from flammable gases. 

Employees are consulted and trained on the process using standard operating procedures. The equipment was designed by engineers. Documentation pertaining to the design of the process and recommended maintenance / integrity inspections are followed. 

Process hazard analysis by HAZOP has been used to identify potential concerns and ensure mitigation to low levels of risk per ALEUS policy. 

If contractors are used on the site, rigorous selection and training specific to the site is performed to ensure potential hazards of contractors are mitigated. 

A hot work program is used to lower risk from hot work. 

Management of change is used for any alterations to the system. 

An incident investigation process applied at multiple facilities in different geographic areas facilitates the timely review of all similar systems operated by Air Liquide ensuring identified risks are mitigated. 

An emergency action plan is utilized. All employees are trained on emergency action plan. 

Audits of the system are conducted periodically and a pre-startup review occurs prior to startup after any significant change.

This facility complies with EPA?s accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The covered bulk tanks were designed / installed and is maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and Washington state law. 

In addition, the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 3322 Road ?N? NE utilizes safety equipment such as:
      -gauges and internal piping to ensure the bulk tanks are operated at or below maximum allowable

working pressure capacity 
      -overpressure relief valves for pressure vessels per ASME code
      -fail-closed emergency shut-off valves 
      -relief valves on compressor piping 
      -process alarms and interlocks in the downstream processes, sensitive to: flows, steam to carbon ratios, pressures, temperatures, and levels 
      -manual emergency shutdown system 
      -nearby water cannons (commonly called monitors) 
      -manual isolation valves 
to safeguard the system, ensure a safe range of operation and actively mitigate events that fall outside of those parameters. 





THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

ALEUS?s 3322 Road ?N? NE location has never had an accident involving hydrogen that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in place. 





THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

ALEUS?s 3322 Road ?N? NE location utilizes an Emergency Action Plan, Emergency Response, Standard Operating Procedures (SOP?s), and Emergency Action Plan Training to ensure personnel are trained to identify and respond to accident and emergency situations.

ALEUS?s 3322 Road ?N? NE location emergency response to accidental releases from the covered process includes:
notification of all persons on site
notification of contiguous industrial site by telephone 
notification of local fire department by telephone
stopping equipment and isolating any equipment which may leak flammable gases
isolation of bulk tank via remote emergency stop 
evacuation of the area
coordination with the local fire department





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

As is our policy at Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP, we continue to review our process(es) for possibilities of improvement to process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk as part of continuous improvement. 

ALEUS performs safety inspections, internal and external safety audits, process hazard analysis, risk analysis, incident and near miss investigations, behavioral audits and site
observations to identify opportunities to improve the process.
